Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Controlling the Synthesis of Conjugated Polymers through Fundamental Studies of Mechanisms, Methods, and the Direct Correlation to Polymer Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this collaborative project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Jason Locklin of University of Georgia and Dr. Wei You of University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill aim to establish new chemical approaches that allow for precise control of sequence, molecular weight, and dispersity in the polymerization of conjugated monomers. These advances are needed to allow for improved structure/property relationships, which are critical for the development of organic polymers for various technologically significant applications including photovoltaics and flexible electronics. This collaborative project promotes multidisciplinary education and research experience at the graduate and undergraduate levels. It is anticipated that graduate students spend time in each other's laboratories acquiring expertise unavailable in the individual research groups, and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering participate in this project through active recruitment. Consequently, participants not only learn new science and develop key technologies, but also build networks of collaborators and contacts and learn important skills for working in interdisciplinary environments. Furthermore, this collaborative project features public outreach to K-12 schools with regular classroom visits to deliver talks on polymers and nanotechnology along with hands-on activities via kit-based science modules.

This collaborative team aims (1) to develop broadly applicable methods to the synthesis of conjugated polymers via controlled chain-growth polymerization in solution, facilitated by a fundamental understanding of the catalytic mechanism using small molecule competition reactions and the kinetic isotope effect, and (2) to evaluate materials in device configurations to determine structure/property relationships of polymers synthesized with high precision versus those prepared with conventional methods. At the conclusion of these studies, this collaborative team anticipates having established a rational and effective method for preparing chain-growth catalysts for selected new monomers and gained a better understanding between structure/property relationships and their correlation to device performance in organic electronic devices. This multi-institutional collaboration integrates the necessary expertise and resources in synthesis and characterization of novel organic molecules and polymers, thin film characterization, and in polymer solar cell device fabrication and characterization. A better understanding of the catalytic cycle with metal-mediated cross coupling reactions and more precise control of an interfacial layer in device geometries will have significant impact on other related fields of organic electronics, such as transistors, light emitting diodes, and fuel cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals

An inter-institutional collaboration involving two research groups (You at UNC Chapel Hill, and Locklin at UGA) have investigated new chemical approaches that allow for precise control of sequence, molecular weight, and dispersity in the polymerization of conjugated monomers. The goal of this work is to (1) establish a rational method for preparing chain growth catalysts for new monomers, in both solution and on surface, and to (2) provide mechanistic insight into the structure/property relationships that are responsible for the failure points in the catalytic cycle of cross coupling reactions relevant to the synthesis of conjugated polymers.

Intellectual Merit

Specifically, through this collaborative project, these two research groups have achieved the following (not exhaustive, only the highlights):

1. Controlling the Orientation of Conjugated Polymer Brushes: we have designed and explored different surface initiators and grown poly(3-methylthiophene) from the surface. Through a comprehensive spectroscopic study, we have illustrated that the subtle control over chain orientation can be achieved using structurally different SAMs

2. Chain Growth Polymerization of D-A Monomers: we have successfully polymerize a D-A monomer through Kumda catalyst transfer polymerization (KCTP) with Ni catalysts, first of its kind.

3. Conjugated Diblock Copolymers: One significant advantage of chain-growth polymerization is the straightforward synthesis of block copolymers, generally achievable by subsequent addition of the second monomer near the complete consumption of the first monomer. With newly developed methodologies, we have achieved conjugated diblock copolymers with precisely defined molecular weights and narrow dispersities.

4. Substrate Scope in the Selective Intramolecular Stille Reaction: we have designed a series of small molecule cross-coupling reactions to probe the breadth of both monomer and catalyst. Monomer substrates were tested based on steric bulk, electronics, and type of aryl halogen bond. The results indicate several factors are of importance in the consideration of a Stille polycondensation reaction: electron density of the aryl substrate, the rate of oxidative addition, and the reactivity of the aryl halide.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts have been significant, including the following.

1. Research results: The fundamental understanding we have gained in the past two years with conjugated polymer synthesis in both solution and on substrate has not only disclosed new insights into this unique chain-growth polymerization, also enabled the synthesis of conjugated diblock copolymers that would be very interesting materials for further applications.

2. Education and training: this project has been a great opportunity to train graduate students and undergraduates as it involves experts from different research fields. This project also helped students to develop research and communication skills and understand challenges involved in other fields and also how to work with researchers from different fields to achieve specific goals.

3. Publication and presentation: some of the results obtained in this work have been published in peer reviewed journals, and the participants (students, postdocs, and faculty members) have given research presentations in various venues.

4. Outreach to general public, and K-12: UNC team has participated in the UNC Science Expo (2015 and 2016) to show the importance of renewable energy. In addition, UNC team also participated in the Climate LEAP program and ran a few lab tours for high school students in the summer of 2015 and 2016.
